question: (1651) Laws passed to make sure that England controlled American trade according to the idea of mercantilism

(1764) The British were deeply in debt partly to French & Indian War, English Parliament placed a tariff on sugar, coffee, wines, and molasses; colonists avoided the tax by smuggling and by bribing tax collectors
(1765) A law passed by the British Parliament requiring colonists to pay a tax on newspapers, pamphlets, legal documents, and even playing cards

(1774) Called the 'Intolerable Acts' by colonists, restricted rights of colonist in Massachusetts to hold town meetings, required all colonists to provide food and housing to British soldiers living in colonies

(1854) Created the territories of Kansas and Nebraska, opened new lands, repealed the Missouri Compromise of 1820, and allowed settlers in those territories to determine if they would allow slavery within their boundaries
(1862) Gave 160 acres of public land to any settler who would farm the land for 5 years
(1882) Banned Chinese immigration to the US for a total of 40 years because the United States consdiered them a threat, caused Chinese population in America to decrease

(1887) Dismantled Native American tribes, set up individuals as family heads with 160 acres, tried to make rugged individualists out of the natives, attempt to assimilate the Native American population into that of white Americans

(1890) First federal action against monopolies, it was signed into law by Benjamin Harrison and was extensively used by Theodore Roosevelt for trust-busting; however, it was initially misused against labor unions
(1906) This act prohibited the manufacture, sale, or shipment of impure of falsely labeled food and drugs

(1913) This act created a central banking system consisting of 12 regional banks governed by the Federal Reserve Board, it was an attempt to provide the United States with a sound yet flexible currency, the Board it created still plays a vital role in the American economy today

(1924) A law that severely restricted immigration by establishing a system of national quotas that blatantly discriminated against immigrants from southern and eastern Europe and virtually excluded Asians, the policy stayed in effect until the 1960s.

(1933) Set by FDR to aide the recovery of the economy from the Great Depression, supported and some cases enforced an alliance of industries, called for industrial self-regulation and declared codes of fair competition

(1930s) Originally designed to avoid American involvement in World War II by preventing loans to those countries taking part in the conflict, they were later modified in 1939 to allow aid to Great Britain and other Allied nations

(1935) Guaranteed retirement payments for enrolled workers beginning at age 65, set up federal-state system of unemployment insurance and care for dependent mothers and children, the handicapped, and public health

(1935) Established National Labor Relations Board; protected the rights of most workers in the private sector to organize labor unions, to engage in collective bargaining, and to take part in strikes and other forms of concerted activity in support of their demands
(1941) A program in which the United States supplied war supplies to the UK, Soviet Union, China, France, and other nations in exchange for military bases in Bermuda and the West Indies

(1947) Outlawed 'closed' shops (closed to non-union members), made unions liable for damages that resulted from jurisdictional disputes among themselves, and required that union leaders take non-communist oaths
(1956) The Eisenhower administration authorized $25 billion for a 10 year project that built over 40,000 miles of interstate highways, this was the largest public works project in American history
(1965) Abolished the national origins quota system, doubled the number of immigrants, and allowed admission of close relatives of the US citizens outside those numerical limits

(1787) Provided for a territorial government in the Northwest Territory, created the framework for territories to apply for statehood, approved by the Second Continental Congress on in 1787, re-enacted by the 1st Federal Congress in 1798
(1803) For approximately $15 million, France ceded Louisiana to the United States, roughly encompassing the territory between the Mississippi River in the east and the Rocky Mountains in the west

(1819) AKA Transcontinental Treaty, provided for Spain’s cession of Florida to the United States, and set the western boundary of the Louisiana Purchase, the United States renounced claims to Texas and took responsibility for $5 million in American citizens’ claims against Spain

(1848) Ended the war between Mexico and the United States. Mexico ceded to the United States control of Texas north of the Rio Grande River, and the territory that eventually made up the states of California, Nevada, Utah, the bulk of New Mexico and Arizona (the Gadsden Purchase of 1853 secured the rest of the territory that comprises these states), and portions of Colorado and Wyoming, the US paid the Mexican government $15 million and assumed $3.25 million in war claims by American citizens, guaranteed Mexican citizens in those territories US citizenship and property rights

(1850) Provided Texas with $10 million, and in return Texas ceded all claims on New Mexico, formally setting the border between the two states, stipulated that New Mexico could enter the Union either as a free or slave state based on its constitution
(1899) Ended the Spanish-American War and Spain ceded Cuba, Guam, Puerto Rico, and portions of the West Indies to the United States, Spain surrendered the Philippines to the U.S. for $20 million

(1900) AKA Organic Act, Established a Puerto Rican government administered by the US President and Congress, with an 11-member executive council, a house of delegates, and a governor; the governor and executive council were all appointed by the US President, designated the island an 'unorganized territory' granting inhabitants 'U.S. national' status but not full US citizenship, provided for biennial elections for a Resident Commissioner - with a non-voting seat in the US House

(1965) Suspended the use of literacy tests and voter disqualification devices for 5 years, authorized the use of federal examiners to supervise voter registration in states that used tests or in which less than half the voting-eligible residents registered or voted, directed the US Attorney General to institute proceedings against use of poll taxes, provided criminal penalties for individuals who violated the act

(1972) Barred schools receiving federal funding from discrimination based on sex, precludes qualified institutions from denying participation in and equal benefits to women for any school-related program or activity

(2010) Constrains the cost of health care for middle-class individuals and families, ensuring that it is available and affordable to all Americans, made it more affordable for a broad range of businesses to offer health coverage to their employees

(1965) Creation of Pell Grants - need-based financial aid that allows students to pay for postsecondary education that might otherwise be out of reach, increased access to college education, expanded pool of college students

(1964) Expansion of human rights to communities of color, religious minorities, and women; allowed them not only to fight back against discrimination in society writ large, but in the workplace as well; created the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission - which ensures that no one is discriminated against on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, or sex

(1944) Formally the Servicemen’s Readjustment Act, after WWII many returning veterans were able to attend college and other postsecondary programs thanks to this bill, the program helped veterans receive grants to pay for higher education, which in turn increased the number of college graduates, expanding access to college education simultaneously boosted the competitiveness of the US and opened up a path to well-paying/middle-class careers to millions of Americans, a similar benefit was extended to veterans of the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the post-9/11 era

(1933) Passed in the wake of the Great Depression, created the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) - the government agency that insures commercial bank deposits, made banking secure and viable for the middle class and offered a means for maintaining and growing savings; although portions of this act have been repealed, the FDIC continues to fulfill this important role today

(1883) AKA Civil Service Reform Act, the act mandates that most positions within the federal government should be awarded on the basis of merit instead of political patronage, ended spoils system (a political patronage practice in which officeholders awarded their allies with government jobs in return for financial and political support) of Gilded Age politics, created the United States Civil Service Commission to enforce the merit system

(1914) Sought to prevent anticompetitive practices in their incipiency, built on Sherman Anti-Trust Act of 1890; specified particular prohibited conduct, the three-level enforcement scheme, the exemptions, and the remedial measures

(1939) Prohibits civil service employees in the executive branch of the federal government, except the president and vice president, from engaging in some forms of political activity, ensures federal programs are administered in a nonpartisan fashion

(1946) Meant to lay the responsibility of economic stability of inflation and unemployment onto the federal government, created the Council of Economic Advisors - mostly microeconomic issues in practice while automatic stabilizers and the Federal Reserve have been used for macroeconomic management

(1940) AKA Alien Registration Act, set criminal penalties for advocating the overthrow of the US government by force or violence, and required all non-citizen adult residents to register with the federal government, used to prosecute communists and socialists, some 1957 SCOTUS decisions would many convictions under the act as unconstitutional

(1947) Major restructuring of the US government's military and intelligence agencies following WWII, establish the National Security Council (NSC) and the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) - the first peacetime/non-military intelligence agency

(1963) Designd to control air pollution on a national level, one of the US's first and most influential environemental laws, one of the most comprehensive air quality laws in the world, administered by the Environemtal Protection Agency (EPA)

(1966) Federal freedom of information law that requires the full or partial disclosure of previously unreleased information and documents controlled by the US government upon request, the act was intended to make U.S. government agencies' functions more transparent so that the American public could more easily identify problems in government functioning and put pressure on Congress, agency officials, and the president to address them

(1968) Part of the Civil Right Act of 1968, intended to protect the buyer or renter of a dwelling from seller or landlord discrimination, its primary prohibition makes it unlawful to refuse to sell, rent to, or negotiate with any person because of that person's inclusion in a protected class, approved by LBJ one week after MLK's assassination

(1970) Labor law governing the federal law of occupational health and safety in the private sector and federal government in the US, its main goal is to ensure that employers provide employees with an environment free from recognized hazards, such as exposure to toxic chemicals, excessive noise levels, mechanical dangers, heat or cold stress, or unsanitary conditions, created its namesake administration and institute - OSHA and NIOSH

(1971) The primary US federal law regulating political campaign fundraising and spending,  originally focused on increased disclosure of contributions for federal political campaigns, the act was amended to create the Federal Election Commission (FEC) and to place legal limits on campaign contributions and expenditures (1974)

(1973) The primary law in the US for protecting imperiled species, designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a 'consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation'

(1974) US federal law that governs the role of the Congress in the US budget process, created the Congressional Budget Office (CBO),  governs the procedures by which Congress annually adopts a budget resolution without POTUS - sets limits on revenues and spending that may be enforced in Congress through procedural objections called points of order

(1986) AKA Immigration Reform and Control Act, altered US immigration law by making it illegal to hire illegal immigrants knowingly and establishing financial and other penalties for companies that employed illegal immigrants, also legalized most undocumented immigrants who had arrived in the country prior to 1/1/1982

(1990) Civil right law that prohibits discrimination based on disability, similar protections to Civil Rights Act (1964), requires covered employers to provide reasonable accommodations to employees with disabilities, and imposes accessibility requirements on public accommodations

(2001) Written following the 9/11 attacks to dramatically tighten US national security especially realted to foreign terrorism, expanded abilities of law enforcement to surveil - including by tapping domestic and international phones, eased interagency communication to allow federal agencies to more effectively use all available resources in counterterrorism efforts, increased penalties for terrorism crimes and an expanded list of activities which would qualify someone to be charged with terrorism

(2001) Reauthorized the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, supported standards-based education reform based on the premise that setting high standards and establishing measurable goals could improve individual outcomes in education,  required states to develop assessments in basic skills, to receive federal school funding - states had to give these assessments to all students at select grade levels, replaced by the Every Student Succeeds Act in 2015

(2002) AKA Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act, amended Federal Election Campaign Act (1971), attempted to address issues with 'soft money' - money donated not to a specific candidate but to a party or committee, attempted to address 'issue advocacy ads' paid for by corporations naming a certain candidate around election time (this provision was overturned by the Citizens United SCOTUS decision)
